moves.1. e4: A short Sicilian game with an interesting checkmate at the end,
moves.5... a6 6. Nd6+ Bxd6 7. Qxd6 Qf6 8. Qd3: One of many alternatives in a fairly common position, with a better winning percentage for White. Black must play carefully.
moves.8... Nh6: ?! An innovation which did not turn out well for Black. It leaves the d5 hole weak and the threat of ...Ng4 is easily parried.
moves.9. Nc3: Since Black has decided not to defend d5, White will control it.
moves.9... Rb8: Preparing for a push down the b file and protecting the rook from Nc7+, but White gets a dangerous initiative here and Black's developmental advantage is suffering. Black was probably concerned that after the more natural ...0-0, 10 Nd5 Qd8 that Bxh6 would leave his K exposed.
moves.10. Nd5: White must strike quickly before Black can regroup, occupying d5 and preparing a quick attack
moves.10... Qd6: ?! This aggressive response exposes Black's queen to tactical threats and makes development harder. Better is the more patient 10 ...Qd8.
moves.11. Bg5: !! I rarely give this rating to my own moves but this is a very subtle but diabolical move with a hidden sting made possible by Black's inaccurate Q move, which is also very difficult to meet effectively. The immediate threat is the somewhat subtle 12 Nf6+! Ke7 (otherwise the Q is lost) 13 Ng4+ f6 14 QxQ+ KxQ  15 NxN PxN 16 BxP with an easily won game. And the natural looking 11 ...0-0? is now met by Ne7+! winning the Q.
moves.11... f6: ?? Wants to drive off the Bishop and probably play 0-0 next move, and is willing to accept Bxh6 doubling and weakening the K side pawns, but misses the primary threat and so loses even more quickly. Black's best move was probably the defensive retreat ...Ng8! and patient defense, although White retains a clear edge.
moves.12. Nxf6+: ! Fairly obvious now but exposing the hidden threat.
moves.13. Ng4+: Forces the K to e6 with check if Black wants to defend the exposed Q.
moves.13... Ke6 14. Qc4+: And my opponent resigns, since checkmate follows after the forced ...Qd5, 15 QxQ#.
